title: R40474
content: This report examines recent laws and congressional proposals regarding gun regulation in the District of Columbia. Key statutes and bills include federal provisions like the National Firearms Act and Gun Control Act, the D.C. Firearms Control Regulation Act, the Second Amendment Enforcement Act (H.R. 645), and the District's Firearms Control Amendment Act and Inoperable Pistol Amendment Act. Congressional proposals often coincide with discussions on voting rights for the District. The report analyzes congressional proposals to amend the District of Columbia's gun laws, focusing on Title II of S. 160 from the 111th Congress and H.R. 645 from the 112th Congress. It discusses the differences between the bills and their potential impact on the District's firearms laws, tracing the proposals section by section. Much of the congressional activity on DC firearms laws followed the Supreme Court's rulings. The report examines congressional proposals to amend DC's gun laws, focusing on S. 160 and H.R. 645. It discusses the impact of the proposals following the Supreme Court's decision in District of Columbia v. Heller, which affirmed an individual's right to possess a firearm for self-defense. The District's Firearms Control Regulation Act had three provisions: (1) barring the registration of handguns, effectively prohibiting their possession; (2) prohibiting carrying a pistol without a license, hindering movement within one's home; and (3) requiring all lawfully owned firearms to be kept unloaded or secured. The Supreme Court's decision did not address the license to carry requirement, leaving room for enforcement if not arbitrary. The DC Council enacted emergency legislation to comply with the Court's ruling. After the Supreme Court's decision in Heller, the DC Council enacted emergency legislation to amend the city's gun laws temporarily. This attempt was met with criticism for not fully complying with the Heller decision. In response, H.R. 6691, the Second Amendment Enforcement Act, was introduced in Congress to potentially loosen provisions of the District's existing gun laws. H.R. 6691, the Second Amendment Enforcement Act, aimed to amend DC's gun laws but did not become law. Its content was included in H.R. 6842, which passed in the House but not the Senate. In the 111th Congress, Senator John Ensign introduced an amendment using the language of H.R. 6842, which was approved and became Title II of S. 160. The Firearms Control Amendment Act of 2008 (FCAA) and the Inoperable Pistol Amendment Act of 2008 (IPAA) were passed by the DC Council and transmitted to Congress for approval. They amended firearms provisions of the DC Code and became effective in March and May 2009. The FCAA and IPAA amended firearms provisions in the DC Code, with new restrictions on firearm regulation and ownership. These amendments were challenged but upheld in court.
